ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NEWATER
(Education on acceptance)


    1. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for the Environment as the Prime Minister has exhorted us to be less reliant on Malaysia for our future water supply, one alternative source is NEWater where there is some public concern over its quality and hygiene standards of "real" cleanliness, what measures have his Ministry in mind to educate Singaporeans to accept NEWater.

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Swee Say): Mr Speaker, Sir, after two years of comprehensive physical, chemical and microbiological analyses of NEWater, the Panel of Experts formed

Column: 424

to study the quality of NEWater has submitted its report to the PUB on 2nd July 2002. The Panel has made public its findings on NEWater at a press conference held last week. Based on some 20,000 test results, the Panel of Experts has concluded that NEWater is safe for drinking. It has met or surpassed all the standards for drinking water set by the World Health Organisation and the US Environmental Protection Agency. In fact, it is even cleaner than PUB water. In line with current practice in the USA on potable use of reclaimed water, the Panel has recommended that NEWater be used for indirect potable use, that is, mixing NEWater with raw water in the reservoirs for further treatment to produce potable water.

    PUB is now studying the Experts Panel's report and findings and will make its recommendation to the Government in about two months' time.

    A summary of the Experts Panel's report will be made available on PUB's NEWater website to be launched on 1st August 2002.

    At the same time, to enhance public understanding of NEWater, PUB has stepped up its public education efforts and will continue to do so in the coming months. PUB has started briefing the grassroots and community leaders a few weeks ago. Our public education programme will cover various areas. For example, to assure the public that NEWater is safe to drink, PUB explains the technology employed in the production of NEWater as well as the quality it is able to attain with NEWater.

    At the same time, to help overcome any psychological barrier, PUB explains the experience of the USA in the use of reclaimed water over the last 20-30 years for indirect potable purpose. At two of the briefing sessions I attended personally, 98% of the grassroots and community leaders, having understood the process involved and the quality achieved in NEWater, indicated that they have no problem in drinking NEWater and accepting

Column: 425

the idea of indirect potable use of NEWater. The other 2% expressed that they still have some psychological barrier and that they would like to understand the process more before they are ready to fully embrace the idea.

    The PUB is now in the process of producing a documentary on NEWater. It will be telecast over the TV channels in August. PUB will make available VCD copies of the NEWater documentary to educational institutions and grassroots organisations.

    By early next year, the public can also come to PUB's new Visitors' Centre at Bedok Water Reclamation Plant to see the actual operations of the NEWater plant. They will be able to see at first hand the use of leading edge membrane technology and ultra-violet process in the production of NEWater.

    Through these efforts in public education, we are confident that Singaporeans will come to recognise that NEWater is indeed a safe, affordable and sustainable source of water supply for Singapore as we strive for greater self-sufficiency in the future.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, in the US where water reclamation has been carried out for more than 20 years, only one or two of the three methods that Singapore is using had been used. Why is there a need for us to go through the three processes in Singapore's case?

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, the USA started the indirect potable use of reclaimed water in the early 70s. In those days, some of these plants were using traditional filtration method. Over the years, with advances in membrane technology, we are now able to achieve better quality at a lower cost. Technology has now made the production of reclaimed water more efficient and cost-effective. In the USA today, indirect potable use of reclaimed water is a growing trend as more and more cities face the challenge of water shortage. Our understanding is that new water reclamation plants in the USA are increasingly using membrane technology.

Column: 426



    The three processes referred by Mdm Ho are what we call the dual-membrane and ultra-violet processes. This combination of processes is gaining popularity. New water reclamation plants in the USA are moving in this direction of adopting dual-membrane and ultra-violet processes. Earlier this year, our NEWater plant was awarded the excellent award by the National Water Research Institution in the USA because we have established a benchmark that is as best as anywhere you can find in the world in terms of our ability to make cost-effective use of technology to produce water quality of the highest standard.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Sir, since one of the three methods was assessed to be sufficient to process the water, as in the US case, to what extent would the incremental value be in having all three processes done for Singapore's case?

    The second question is: would the additional two or three processes not be adding to the cost of processing the water and who would then be bearing this additional cost?

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, firstly, let me explain that even though dual-membrane is a two-step process, it does not necessarily lead to higher cost. Let me explain. With reverse osmosis, we are going to achieve the highest quality of water. What this means is that before the water goes through reverse osmosis, it has to go through a stage of preparation first. The whole purpose of micro-filtration or ultra-filtration used in the first step of membrane application is to filter out bigger size impurities, for example, bacteria. By the time it comes to reverse osmosis, the process will be filtering out, for example, viruses which are much smaller than bacteria, as well as estrogenic compounds which are again much smaller than viruses and bacteria.

    Basically, the whole process is to remove impurities in a two-stage approach. In this way, not only will we be able to achieve higher quality water but, at the same time, we will be able to optimise the cost performance of dual membrane.

Column: 427

On the whole, it will lead to better cost optimisation.

    Secondly, Mdm Ho asked who will bear the additional cost. Sir, I want to emphasise that the introduction of NEWater does not add to higher cost of future water supply in Singapore. In fact, the whole purpose of introducing NEWater is to reduce the increased cost of future supply of water in Singapore. Members of the House will remember that until the concept of water reclamation came about, the next alternative for Singapore was really to go for desalination. I have mentioned in this House on 22nd May 2002 that when you compare the cost of water reclamation - NEWater versus desalination - in terms of capital cost, the cost for NEWater is about half that of desalination. In terms of energy consumption, it is about one-quarter to one-fifth that of desalination. As a result, the total cost of NEWater production is about half that of desalination. In other words, the introduction of NEWater actually helps us to prevent the need to increase the prices of water in the future because with this lower cost alternative, we are now able to better contain the cost of water in the future.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister how soon does he think that the Government will want to use NEWater for domestic purposes.

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, as I have mentioned earlier, PUB is now looking into the recommendation by the Experts Panel and PUB expects to put forward its recommendation to the Government sometime in September. Based on PUB's recommendation, the ENV will then work out the introduction plan. At this moment, I would not want to jump the gun because the next step is for PUB to study the recommendation from the Experts Panel carefully so that by the time it comes to a decision, we will be able to move forward with complete confidence.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether there is any plan to

Column: 428

use NEWater directly and whether there is any need to improve the NEWater further by altering the PH of the NEWater after production?

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, NEWater will be used in two ways. Firstly, for non-potable use in industry and the commercial sector, NEWater will be used directly. This will begin in January next year.

    Dr Lily Neo asked whether there is any need to adjust the PH level of NEWater. The answer is yes, because NEWater is so pure that the PH level at this moment is about 6.2 to 6.5 which is below the neutral level of 7. So what PUB will do is that NEWater, after production, will be stabilised before it is delivered to the wafer fab plants starting in January next year.

    The second purpose is for potable use. As I have mentioned earlier, the Experts Panel is recommending that we make use of NEWater for potable use in an indirect manner. This means pumping NEWater into the reservoir and mixing it with raw water in the reservoir. From there, it will be reprocessed again into PUB water.

Column: 428

INTEGRATION OF MAIN RESERVOIRS


    2. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for the Environment, in view of our Prime Minister mentioning the possibility of joining our three main reservoirs into one huge catchment area, has his Ministry carried out an environmental impact study whether such a project should, in fact, be carried out.

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe the Member is referring to PUB's plan to integrate the various reservoirs to enhance the overall yield of our local catchments. By linking up the various reservoirs, PUB will be able to balance any mismatch between the amount of rainfall collected in the catchment areas and their respective reservoir storage capacities. This linking-up is done through underground pipelines. PUB therefore does not expect any adverse environmental impact.

Column: 429



    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Has any study been done or carried out to examine possible implications of such a project?

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, as I have mentioned, the linking-up of the reservoirs will be done through underground pipelines and therefore there will not be any effect from the environmental or biodiversity angle. In that sense, I want to assure the House that the linking-up of the reservoirs through underground pipelines will have no adverse impact on the environment.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: I would like to check with the Minister whether there will be any excavation work done to lay these pipes.

    Mr Lim Swee Say: Sir, the answer is yes, it will be done just like the way we lay the various telecommunication cables, water pipes, the MRT tunnels and the DTSS. There is no difference. Measures will be taken to minimise inconvenience to the public.

Column: 429

ASIA COOPERATION DIALOGUE
(Singapore's position)


    3. Mr R. Ravindran asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs what is Singapore's position on the proposal by Thailand to create an Asia Co-operation Dialogue.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, Thailand hosted the first meeting of the Asia Cooperation Dialogue (ACD) from 18-20th June this year. I was among the 17 representatives from Asian participating countries.

    When Prime Minister Goh visited Thailand in February this year, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra asked for Singapore's support for his proposal on the Asia Cooperation Dialogue. Prime Minister agreed to support this initiative. We supported it in view of our long-standing approach of advocating a more outward and forward-looking ASEAN and Asia.

Column: 430



    The ACD hopes to bring together countries in West Asia, the Gulf countries, South Asia, ASEAN and East Asia. Although there are many existing regional and sub-regional organisations in Asia, such as ASEAN, ARF, South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC), Indian Ocean Rim Association for Regional Cooperation (IOR-ARC) and the Gulf Cooperation Council, there is, however, minimal interaction between them. The ACD, if properly nurtured, could eventually bridge the gap between these different regional groupings in Asia.

    At the recent ACD meeting, all the Foreign Ministers present were of the view that the organisation was a good and timely idea, but they cautioned that the ACD must be inclusive, not a closed grouping nor should it be a regional bloc. It should also avoid duplicating the work of existing regional organisations. The meeting also discussed many ideas and proposals aimed at promoting greater cooperation within Asia. Singapore's own suggestion was that the ACD countries could cooperate in the area of SMEs, because SMEs comprise a large segment of employment in Asia.

    Sir, I believe that the ACD could facilitate closer cooperation amongst SMEs in the region. Singapore will work closely with Thailand which is the coordinator for the ACD in the coming year.

Column: 430

AVERAGE EARNINGS OF FEMALES AND WAGE GAP BETWEEN MEN AND WOMEN



    4. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Manpower (a) what are the average monthly earnings of resident females from 1997 - 2001; and (b) whether the wage gap between men and women is getting narrower.

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, based on the Central Provident Fund Board's records, the average monthly earnings of females increased from $2,256 in 1998 to $2,588 in 2001, or at a rate of 4.7% per annum during the period. After discounting for

Column: 431

inflation, the real earnings rose from $2,263 to $2,535 at an annualised rate of 3.9% during the same period. Earnings data prior to 1998 are not comparable due to a change in the collection methodology. The hon. Member asked for data from 1997. Because of the change in collection methodology, I gave the figures for 1998 onwards.

    Sir, females in Singapore generally earn less than males at the aggregate level. This is not unlike the experience in many other countries. In 2001, the average monthly earnings of females was 72% that of males. This reflects the higher concentration of females in lower paying occupations due to the poorer educational attainment of the older cohorts of female workers. The tendency for females to withdraw from the workforce because of childcare and household responsibilities also reduced the average years of service and experience of working females. With our seniority-based wage system, females, as a group, will therefore earn less than males. For the younger age group, the wage gap differential is generally smaller. In fact, in the age group of 25 to 29, women working as managers, professionals, associate professionals and technicians, and service and sales workers actually earn more than their male counterparts. Other factors contributing to the gender wage disparity include differences in skills, qualifications, age, job nature and position.

    The wage gap was largely unchanged over the last few years. It was also 72% in 1998.

    Sir, the underlying concern in Dr Neo's question on wage gap is whether women in Singapore are discriminated against in employment. Average monthly earnings of women have significantly increased over the years. While differences in wages still exist, I would like to emphasise that it is not the result of discrimination at work. Rather, it is due to legitimate work-related reasons such as working experience, years of service, types of jobs held and skills, as I mentioned earlier.

Column: 432



    The Government's policy on employment is based on the principles of equal opportunities and meritocracy. Our employment practice emphasises equal opportunities for all, and a reward system based on performance. The Singapore Civil Service adopted the principle of equal pay for equal work since 1962. NTUC and its affiliated unions make no distinction between male or female members. In collective agreements signed between unions and employers, the principle of equal pay for work of equal value is the norm. In addition, the National Wages Council, which is the national tripartite advisory body on wages, formulates wage increase guidelines each year based on key economic indicators, such as GDP growth, productivity, inflation and international competitiveness. This has enabled Singapore workers, both men and women, to enjoy a fair share of the fruits of economic growth.

    Dr Lily Neo: Sir, may I ask the Minister whether he is satisfied with the rate of the narrowing of the wage gap in the past five years? What has his Ministry done to narrow this gap? And what else can be done to further accelerate the narrowing of this wage gap?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, we cannot say that we are completely satisfied with the situation. We will want to work towards a point in future that the skills and qualifications of the women workers are equal to that of men, so that they will be able to earn the same pay. On a national basis, looking in total, this will take time, because we still have many cohorts of older women. And if we look at the education of the older women, they tend to lag behind that of their male counterparts in the same age cohort. The way to narrow this gap is, in fact, through education. As I mentioned earlier on in my main reply, in the age group of 25 to 29, the women actually earn more than the men. And through better education, we will find the women entering the labour force will have as good an education, and as good a training as their male counterparts, and they will earn the same wages as their male counterparts. So, with education, we will gradually narrow the gap.

Column: 433



    What has the Ministry done? In terms of continuing education and training, my Ministry also makes no distinction between male and female workers. We give equal encouragement and support to women who come forward to undergo skills retraining or upgrading. In fact, we have many programmes which help the lower skilled workers, and you will find a disproportionate number of women among the lower skilled. They are the ones who stand to best benefit from this programme for skills upgrading. And we will continue to implement programmes to help the lower skilled to uplift their skills for the new jobs in the new economy. This is the way for us to speed up the narrowing of the wage gap.

    What else can be done? As I said, we will continue to look at more skills upgrading programmes for the cohorts of women who are already in the workforce, particularly the older women in their 40s and above. They have poorer education and lower level of skills. The way for them to narrow the wage gap is, in fact, to go for skills upgrading, and take advantage of the many programmes that we have, whether it is the National Skills Recognition System, the Skills Redevelopment Programme or one of our strategic manpower conversion programmes that will help them to acquire new skills for jobs in different areas. If they take these opportunities to upgrade themselves, I am sure they will be able to earn a higher wage.

    Dr Lily Neo: Sir, may I ask the Minister for the outcome of the study which he agreed to look into when I raised the issue of the wage gap in 1997 on the challenges faced by women in employment, such as the general opinion of the employers with regard to the role of women in the workplace, and also the difficulty of balancing work with family responsibilities?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1997, or earlier than that, my Ministry has been actively promoting family-friendly human resource management practices. We have given awards to recognise firms with practices which are actually family-friendly, particularly for their women workers. We will continue to

Column: 434

do so. We will continue to explore how we can encourage companies and employers to adopt family-friendly practices for their female workers in order to allow them to better balance their career and also the needs of the mothers and wives to manage the home. These are issues which are constantly being looked at.

    With regard to the specific study that the hon. Member said that she raised in 1997, I have to look it up, because I do not have the answer with me right now.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Sir, one of the reasons cited for the wage gap of females compared to their counterparts is that they have withdrawn from the workforce to mind their children. I would like to ask the Minister whether there is a possibility for a scheme to be examined which is similar to the National Service scheme for NSmen to make up for the loss of their 21/2 years' national service training. Normally, they are given increments. For women who withdraw from the workforce to do their "national service" in looking after their children, if they should re-enter the workforce, is there a chance for them to be given some kind of recognition for the "national service" that they have performed, so that we minimise the wage gap between male and female workers?

    Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think there is a tendency to try to draw parallels all over the place, and we can arrive at very unusual conclusions. The reason why Government gives increments to NSmen within the civil service and encourages the private sector to give the males who have to perform 21/2 years of national service the same recognition is self-evident. Because they have to give up 21/2 years of their career to perform national service at a very nominal allowance from the Ministry of Defence. So, we try to make up for them by encouraging employers in the private sector and in the civil service to give them two increments when they join the service.

    As for women taking time off to mind their families and look after the children, I think there are many other ways people can balance work and home. To have a

Column: 435

rigid structure whereby you say that the employer will have to pay the woman worker X number of credits by way of increments upon rejoining the company after a certain number of years, I think this would increase the rigidity in our labour market. The more rigid we make our labour market, the more difficult it is for us to achieve the kind of growth and competitiveness that we want. The world is not getting any more friendlier in terms of economic competition. On the contrary, competition is heating up. The more we introduce these little tweaks here and there, the more difficult we will make it for the women to get work in the future. So, far from helping women, such rigidity may discriminate against women.

    I would therefore urge Members to be careful when advancing ideas about how we want to help the women. The way to help them is actually through education and skills training. If we equip them well, they will be needed by the employers when the economy turns around and picks up. They will command a wage that the market will decide and the employers will pay. If we try to include all these little ideas of how to favour them, we will discourage employers from employing more women. So, let us be very careful about what we want to do. Are we here to help the women workers to bridge the gap, or are we going to make life more difficult for them? I would urge you to be very circumspect in proposing such measures. On the part of the Government, we will continue to try to help and equip our women workforce, which is half of the population. If we do not give them every means to upgrade themselves so that they can perform well in the new economy, then we are doing ourselves a serious disservice.

    Let me assure all hon. Members that Government will pay particular attention to the needs of the women workers, to help them bridge this gap.

    Dr Jennifer Lee (Nominated Member): Sir, I think definitely making things structurally rigid is not good. But I would like to

Column: 436

ask the Minister what his Ministry and, in fact, all the other Ministries that he might be able to influence, are doing, in terms of actually changing mindset, and this is where Government can take the lead, because promoting responsibility of the father and husband is a very important thing. I think the recent changes in child sick leave is a good example. But will his Ministry pursue and encourage right across civil service more of this type of benefits? In fact, the approach and the mindset of Government should be to encourage better sharing of responsibilities, because ultimately that is, in fact, the way to go.

In the event of a loan default, the CPF Board assumes priority charge over the mortgaged property, ahead of the banks. This means that, in the event of borrower default, the banks are unable to make effective use of the mortgaged property to mitigate their losses. This is because proceeds from the liquidation of the property will first have to be used to repay the CPF Board, ie, to repay the borrower's own CPF account. And as the loan matures and more of it is repaid through CPF withdrawals, the Board's claims increase correspondingly. The banks are entitled to a diminishing residual amount after the money has been returned to the buyers' CPF account. Hence, the more loan is repaid with CPF, the less satisfactory the bank's collateral position becomes. This is not sound for the banking system.

    So far this has not posed any major problems, because over the past decades, the property market has risen steadily and strongly, especially in the 80s and early 90s when the economy was booming. colleagues from the labour movement to ask the Government to consider giving them extra shares or CPF top-ups, as and when the Government makes such payments.

    On this note, Sir, I support the changes to the CPF.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the CPF scheme has been set up to ensure that the people have enough savings to satisfy their retirement needs. But over the past years, the conditions and rules governing our CPF system have gradually been relaxed.     Because of this, any change to the employer's CPF contribution rate would attract a lot of attention as it has formed a component part of the wages of the people. In a bad time, a reduction in employers' CPF contribution is advocated as a means to help the employers tide over the troubled waters to ensure that jobs are saved, and the workers are asked to make sacrifices in order that they can go through the difficult period together with the employers. This kind of sacrifice is worthwhile. At this time when the economy is beginning to pick up, we are proposing to cut their CPF contributions because of new factors and circumstances. I think such an arrangement at this time warrants our further deliberation.

Column: 511

They have enough means to look after themselves.

    What the Government said was only partially correct. The incorrect part is that why the 20% employer's contribution from $5,000 to $6,000 is taken away. Under this new measure, before the employee could flexibly manage the $200 per month of reduced employee's contribution, he already loses $200 due to the cut in the employers' CPF contribution.     In the report, it was also recommended that employers' CPF contribution for workers aged 50-55 be frozen at 16%. In other words, for employees in this age group, when the employers' CPF contribution rate for the other workers is fully restored to 20%, theirs will be frozen at 16%. The reason given for this proposed change is to ensure that people in this age group who are unemployed will find it easier to get a job, and those currently employed will not be retrenched so readily. I have some doubts on this measure.

    First, from the way it is worded, I observe that this measure is to tackle a problem when there is retrenchment and high unemployment rate. This is the

Column: 512

presumption for this measure to be taken. In other words, when the economy has recovered, and there is full employment, there will be no meaning to this measure, except that the wages of the workers are reduced.

    From 1988 until today, the economic performance of Singapore was good for about 70-80% of the time. There were only about 20-30% of the time when our economy was bad. The contribution rate of CPF should be based on the good times and make adjustment when the economy is bad. In other words, we should not use the standard made for the bad times as a general policy. This is because when the economy has recovered, all these cuts and reductions in the CPF contribution rates are unable to be restored because it is a general policy. The consequence is that the workers are unable to make good their losses.

If this assumption is correct, and it is also reflected generally, then we should take a look at our Members in this House today. More than 50% of our Members of Parliament are above the age of 50. From this angle, we can see clearly one point, ie, age is not a hindrance to employability. Cutting of the employer's CPF contribution is not the solution to their employability.

Does it mean that once their CPF contribution rate is reduced to 16%, they will automatically get employment? Before the full recovery of our economy, their employability will mean the unemployability of other people. One older worker employed will mean one younger worker unemployed. Using the same argument, do we want to cut the CPF contribution rate of these younger workers to 16% to help them get employment?

Column: 513



    What will happen if our economy is fully recovered? The workers enjoy full employment and, again, the foreign worker population rises above 500,000. All the workers aged between 50-60 are no longer faced with the employability pressure. My question is whether we will base on the same argument to reinstate their CPF contribution. The argument is when employability is low we cut their CPF. When there is no such employability pressure, should not the CPF be restored?

    From the above points raised, I have a lot of doubts about this measure. I feel that the argument of freezing the CPF of those aged 50-55 at 16% to ensure that they keep their jobs or help the retrenched workers to find jobs is weak.

    Despite the strong negative opinion on the cut in employer's CPF contribution, there are also many other ERC's recommendations on changes to our existing CPF system.     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, I would like to commend the Economic Review Committee in adopting a consultative approach to discuss with the people and also to consider all the impacts on the people from all walks of life before they make their recommendations.

Since the time of independence, we have been proud of our CPF system as it serves as a safety net for the welfare of our people. With this CPF safety net, we facilitated the implementation of the home ownership scheme for our people and took care of healthcare expenses for our people through the Medisave scheme.

Column: 514

Apart from its role as a social safety net, the CPF scheme has also been used as a sort of buffer in adjusting the wages of our workers during the bad times. If we do not have CPF, then we would have to hit on the actual wages of our workers, and I think it would be more difficult for us to recover from a recession.

The functions and roles of CPF are becoming more and more complicated. Now, CPF is also used as an adjuster for the employability of our workers!

It was then turned down. I am glad that it has now been recommended by the ERC. So, I hope that on this occasion, more women would take advantage of this scheme to get back to the workforce. Just now, the Minister for Manpower has said that we may delay this scheme because of the economic recession. I beg to differ. If we want to improve our productivity, we should encourage more women to return to the workforce. One of the important points is that we should encourage more flexible

Column: 515

work schemes or part-time jobs for the women, particularly when their husbands are retrenched or unemployed. It will be all the more important that the women return to the workforce. They can help to support the family.

    As for the reduction of CPF contribution rate from 40% to 32% for older workers between the ages of 50 and 55, this is one of the most hotly discussed topics. For workers in this age group, they will not see their employers' CPF contribution rate restored to 20% when the others finally get theirs.

    According to the South West Community Development Council's job-matching data, those who are affected by economic recession and have come to us for help in getting a job, some 30.5% are from the 40-49 age group and 13% from the 50-59 age group. So, strictly speaking, those who are affected are not confined to workers between the ages of 50 and 59. Even those who are 40 and above are already affected by this retrenchment trend. I was quite surprised by the figures.

    After some consultation, the Government's recommendation now is to reduce the CPF rates only for those between 50 and 55. Of course, the presumption is that by reducing the labour cost on these workers, the employers will be less inclined to retrench them and they stand a better chance of retaining their jobs. But whether or not this will create employability, I think we have to look further into it. Employability concerns not only the labour cost, but also on other attributes of the workers such as work attitude, competence, ability to work as a team, etc. I hope the Ministry of Manpower would set up a committee to look into the employability of workers who are 40 years and above and conduct more in-depth study into their employability issues. A number of schemes are already in place to help them but whether or not they are effective, we do not know. We have also introduced this incentive for lifelong learning. But has this been proven to be effective?

Column: 516



    Another point that I would like to bring up concerns the 4% reduction in employers' CPF contribution. I would suggest we set aside 1% for a Personal Training Account in the CPF. This point has been brought up several times before. I think this will tell the workers that we do not want just to reduce their CPF, but we want to set aside part of it to set up a training account for them. Perhaps, 1% should be used to set up a training account in their CPF.

    Another point is that I feel that employers should be more positive in their attitude. Over the years, we have read a lot of reports in the newspapers concerning discussions on how to reduce business cost, including labour cost. As reflected in these reports, it is always the trade unions and the Government who are actively pursuing the matter. Very little has been reported on the employers' involvement in this. We talk a lot about globalisation nowadays. But it is always the Government which is doing the talking. In other countries, all sorts of projects are initiated by the private sector, eg, IBM, AT&T, Johnson & Johnson, etc, whereby the workers are briefed on the global trend of business and the company's reaction to all these changing trends. This would enable the workers to know what direction their company is heading towards so that they could do the necessary adjustment and make early preparation to adapt to all these changes. But in Singapore, our employers are not very active. Here in Singapore, only the MCDS is doing this sort of thing. I feel that we should explain to our workers the perspective of the employers, let them know the competition that we are facing and the various aspects of globalisation.

    I feel our employers should not wait for the Government to solve their problems for them. They should be more proactive in explaining to the workers the importance of training and the importance of enhancing their productivity.

    Another point I would like to touch on is the Minimum Sum. At the moment, our target is $80,000 but after 2003, it is suggested that it goes beyond $80,000. I

Column: 517

personally support this because with our families going into nuclear family units, many senior citizens need to work to support themselves. Of course, we want our children to be filial to their parents. But nowadays, we can see there are more single parents and a lot of people have no children to support them. With the increase in the Minimum Sum, better protection will be provided for the old folks to meet their retirement needs.

    As for those higher income workers, we have now reduced the income ceiling for CPF contributions. I feel that they should be able to take care of themselves because they are among the top 12% of our population. The Government has introduced the Supplementary Retirement Scheme whereby the high income earners can set aside additional savings in it to earn better interest. I would like to know what is the take-up rate for this scheme since its implementation.

    Many people have been investing in shares. I do not think that many of them have actually made profits from there. Perhaps, we should have more education programmes for our CPF members so that they would know how to invest wisely. I think most Singaporeans do not have a good enough knowledge on how to invest their money.

    Generally, the people's reaction to these recommendations to change our CPF system is certainly not as hotly debated as the earlier 3-cent increase in bus fares. I think this is probably due to the prior consultative approach by the Government. Singaporeans are very rational. They understand that under this globlisation trend, in order to retain our competitiveness, we have to reform. But I urge the ERC and MOM to set up a committee to review and to re-assess the effect of all our training schemes so that they could be implemented more effectively and workers who are 40 and above would increase their employability.

    I support the Ministerial Statement.

    Mr R. Ravindran (Marine Parade): Sir, we have literally come one full circle.

Column: 518

When the CPF scheme was set up in 1955, it started off as a very conservative scheme. In the 1980s and 1990s, we started on a liberal track and now, we are trying to be back on the conservative route.

    Sir, on the whole, I congratulate the ERC Sub-Committee on its recommendations in focusing on the three key aims of the CPF, which are housing, medical care and old-age subsistence. Sir, the recommendations remove the uncertainty in the property market and, hopefully, will bring about a sustainable and rational property market.

    I welcome the proposal to increase the contribution to the Special Account by 1%. Sir, I remember when I sat on the Inter-Ministry Committee on Ageing, one of the concerns of the Committee was whether, when people reach old age, they have sufficient savings in their CPF account. I am very happy to see that this recommendation has been included in the ERC and is seeing fruition.

    Sir, I agree with the ERC that the amount set aside for our old-age subsistence should be increased gradually to adjust for cost of living and increasing income. I also welcome the measure to give low-income workers more take-home pay by raising the employee CPF wage band to $500-$750. I am confident that this would also encourage more to join the workforce and enjoy a bigger take-home pay.

    Sir, let me now move on to the issue of employability of older workers in the age group of 50-55 years whose employer and employee CPF rates will be capped at 16%. I would like to ask the DPM whether reducing the CPF rates for this group will increase their employability. The market mechanism, as it is, determines the salary of these older workers. Many who were re-employed after their retrenchment were actually re-employed at lower salaries.

    Sir, I understand that the unemployment figure for this age group is about 11%. This is due to the present economic climate. I remember watching a Channel

Column: 519

NewsAsia interview last week which highlighted that for many employers, the reduction of the employers' CPF rate would not make them recruit older workers. Sir, I sincerely have my doubts whether this measure would really help the older workers.

    For a start, I would like to ask the DPM as to how many older workers have been recruited by the Government over the last few years and whether the latest CPF cut would mean that the Government itself would set an example by recruiting older workers.

    Sir, it would help to give us a better gauge as to whether this measure will have the impact that it really intends to have. My sense is that we have unnecessarily cut the wages of 89% of the workers in trying to solve this problem. In addition, I would like to ask whether we can expect the private sector to reward older workers by channelling the reduced CPF contribution to the monthly variable component of the salaried staff. Sir, as Mdm Halimah highlighted, as it is, only 4.8% of the private sector employers contribute to this or have started implementing this monthly variable component. For a start, to expect the employers to include this is itself an uphill task. And I wonder whether this will have the desired effect in asking the employers in the private sector to pass on the cost saving in this CPF cut to the employers.

    Sir, as it is, it is not a mandatory measure and to expect the employers to do so without any mandatory requirement, I think is a very difficult exercise and I am not sure whether we will succeed. Perhaps, we could have carefully considered this particular measure. Upgrading their skills, creating more jobs would have been a better option and even perhaps having this as a short-term measure and reverting back to a 20% employer-employee contribution would be better when the economy recovers.

    Sir, let me now move on to the changes in the CPF housing scheme. Here, there

Column: 520

are many questions which are thrown up, which I am quite sure many Singaporeans want to know the answers. First of all, was there a real necessity to tinker with the system which has served us well? CPF members' savings were protected, as the bank mortgage took second priority to the CPF charge in private property purchases. However, this has now changed. When there is nothing fundamentally wrong with the present arrangement, why change the regime?

    Secondly, once the banks are given priority in unsubsidised housing loans for HDB flats and they are entitled to take possession and sell these flats when the owners default, it throws up a bigger question. Many creditors whose debtors are staying in HDB flats will now pressure and ask the Government if private banks can now take over HDB properties and realise their loans. Certainly other creditors out there will pressure the Government to open up the HDB property to be seized by other creditors to whom the owner of the flat owes them money. And do we move on to the second stage and remove this protection for subsidised HDB flats away from these creditors?

    Thirdly, to-date, HDB is very sympathetic to HDB borrowers. It grants them extended periods to pay if they are in financial difficulties, and repossession is a measure of last resort. How will the Government then ensure that such measures will be in place to provide a buffer for such people? And I am quite sure the number of people who are going to take loans from the private banks for purchasing HDB flats will only grow in number. The next time a recession comes along, I think there will be a greater expectation on the part of this group of Singaporeans to pressure the Government to pressure the banks to withhold taking action against them. Sir, I wonder whether the Government will take into account the interest of the bank or the interest of the borrowers in trying to arrive at a solution that is palatable to both groups.

    Sir, the second element is that, at the moment, the interest rate in the market is

Column: 521

very attractive. As such, many will go and take a loan. But in future, interest rates will increase and many of the borrowers will default on their loans. Again, the question arises: how do we temper the pain that the population will face when interest rates rise?

    Fourthly, another issue that again arises is that when the bank repossesses the property and the mortgage sale proceeds are unable to satisfy the amount withdrawn from the CPF account, will the CPF Board pursue full legal remedies against the members? Because, at the moment, if one has paid up the CPF account and the bank is not paid in full, the bank will take legal action to recover the full amount. But with the new scenario, when the member is unable to pay up the CPF amount in full, my question is: will the CPF Board take legal action, including making one bankrupt, to make sure that his account is repaid back?

    Fifthly, Sir, by allowing the 10% downpayment to be paid from the CPF account, whether this will kick start the property market and actually go against the anti-speculation measures that we have in place as far as the property market is concerned.

    Sixthly, in the past, reverse mortgages were not feasible, because HDB properties were considered sacrosanct. But now, with the liberalising of the HDB property market and by allowing banks to provide loans, my question is whether reverse mortgages can be considered as a serious alternative; and, as such, whether we can allow more Singaporeans to cash out of their property while they are staying in it.

    Sir, on those notes, let me once again welcome the major recommendations of the Economic Review Committee, and I am quite sure that many of the intended purposes of the Committee will see light.

    Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to speak on the changes to the CPF scheme.

    It is nearly half-a-century-long legacy, the CPF has created Singaporeans to be

Column: 522

one of the world's highest home owning population. I congratulate the move now by the Government to take stock of the CPF and to re-evaluate it.

    Sir, I would like to focus on five points. My first concern is the alarming trend that over the years, CPF has been heavily relied upon for home ownership. I feel that too much of our savings in the CPF has been devoted for our housing needs. I wish to highlight statistics to support my concern. As of 31st March 2002, $92 billion has been withdrawn from the CPF Board for the purchase of properties, out of which about two-thirds are used for public housing. From January to March this year alone, $3 billion was used for the purchase of properties, with 70% of it tied up in public housing schemes. In comparison, only $510 million is for retirement, and $114 million for healthcare.

    My second concern is the depletion of the value of homes in deflationary times. As rightly put forth by the Economic Review Committee, the property market has an impact on many things. To the many Singaporeans outside this House, they are most concerned with the impact on individual household, financial condition and asset value. Let me elaborate. When property prices rise, we see a parallel increase in withdrawal in our CPF savings, which is allowed based on the formula of withdrawal at 150% of the value of the property. I agree with the recommendation that this be gradually lowered to 120%, the reason being when property values drop in a deflationary period and negative asset value is experienced as too much money has been spent on buying that asset. At present, some Singaporeans have already experienced a permanent depletion of their CPF savings as a result. The value of their properties has fallen and may not rise again to the level of their purchase price. Today, the ownership of this form of asset, if not fully paid for, may prove to be a liability if there is insufficient balance in one's CPF account.

    To curb such excessive spending, we must go back to the original purpose of our CPF savings - that of meeting our

Column: 523

retirement needs. We need to avoid a situation where Singaporeans are cash poor and asset poor when they retire. We must therefore create a public awareness programme to dissuade Singaporeans from spending on property in anticipation of a double digit growth in our economy, as was seen in the late 80s and a good part of the 90s. Those years saw the value of properties rising beyond the reach of most Singaporeans. But the booming property market has led many to throw caution to the wind. To expect such time again is but an illusion. With Singapore becoming a more mature economy towards a developed nation, growth rates of a single digit such as 3-5% will become a norm. Future growth in property prices will follow economic trends, and we will not see fast rising property market for some time to come. The need to fork out cash under the new recommendation would help Singaporeans to be more realistic in buying a home not beyond their means.

    Sir, next, I wish to draw DPM's attention to the move to allow banks to participate in granting housing loans to HDB property owners. This is indeed a bold move by the Government. Not only does it allow interest rates to be pegged to market rates, it also allows banks to have first claim against the property before the CPF Board. However, to attract banks to participate in this sector, a strong resale market must be in place to allow banks to have a second hand market to dispose of properties in the event of a default by the borrowers. Here, HDB will have to monitor carefully the supply side of the market and avoid an over supply, thus encouraging buyers from choosing new flats as opposed to old ones in the resale market. Some Singaporeans have voiced concern over the banks taking on their role. They are worried that banks, being what they are, profit-making corporations will be less lenient and less ready to help the man-in-the-street during economic downturns as compared to the Government. Banks are accountable to their shareholders and are concerned about their bottom line. I would like to ask the

Column: 524

Minister whether safety nets will be put in place to help families whose homes might be seized by the banks and left homeless.

    Sir, another problem I wish to highlight is the availability of cash if the balances in CPF savings are not going to be sufficient enough to cater for retirement needs. Statistics from the CPF Board in the year 2000 show that more than 600,000 CPF members have less than $80,000, the Minimum Sum required to be maintained in their accounts by July next year. As more responsibilities in managing CPF savings are passed down to contributors to the Fund, a liberal use of CPF for investment in the Ordinary Account must surely be reduced gradually. The Ordinary Account should be encouraged to grow in the same proportion, if not more than the Special Account. This is to ensure that savings in the CPF are close to sufficient for old age. Total CPF funds invested as at 31st March 2002 stood at $26 billion. Total funds still available for investment in the Ordinary and Special Accounts are $52 billion and $12 billion respectively. Furthermore, the balance in the Special Account of $80,000 - the Minimum Sum to be maintained in the CPF account - will not meet the needs of most Singaporeans as the standard of living rises and people tend to live longer. To counter this vulnerability, the Government has recommended to increase cash available at retirement by raising CPF contribution to members' Special Accounts by one percentage point once CPF rates are restored to 40%, requiring the CPF to pay a higher and more appropriate long-term interest rate on Special Account balances and raising the Minimum Sum to be kept in CPF accounts beyond the current level of $80,000. These efforts may be too late and too little for some. As most Singaporeans have a home now and as income potential drops, as one gets older or is retrenched, the temptation to convert their property to cash to supplement their CPF increases. This then may result in a whole new spectrum of housing problems for this group of people, as they have to find alternative housing. What I foresee is a class of rental housing may eventually have to be created to meet this possible future need.

Column: 525



    Last but not least, I would like to voice my concern on the CPF rate for older workers. Under the proposal, older workers will see their total CPF contribution capped at 32%, down from the current 36%. Their own contribution rate will also be down from 20% to 16%. This will be implemented when the Government restores the targeted CPF contributions. The Deputy Prime Minister has assured us that this will not likely to happen until 2-4 years later. The rationale for the move was to assist workers in this age bracket, as they are viewed to be at greater risk of being retrenched, but will also have more difficulty of finding work at their last drawn pay. I beg to differ. The proposed reduction alone will not achieve its good intention of retaining jobs for the 50-55-year old workers. Workers in this age bracket will have to change their mindset in order not to be left behind in a changing business and social environment. In this respect, I hope that the Government will speed up its efforts in retraining this group of people, such as in the Skills Redevelopment Programme and the People-for-Job Traineeship Programme. Moreover, the decrease in employee's contribution from 20% to 16% eventually will mean less CPF savings and a higher income tax bill for high-income earners. This may lead to employees asking for lower monthly salary with a higher year end bonus. This is because bonuses have no limits in CPF contribution as long as total CPF contributions do not exceed 40% of total income for the year. If this trend catches on, then the change in contribution rate for those in the 50-55 year brackets to 32% will not make any difference to this class of people, thus neutralising the effect of changes to CPF contribution.

    In conclusion, I support wholeheartedly the recent changes by the Government to mark the broad path to CPF rate in the future by introducing fine adjustments to the system, rather than drastic changes, allowing a stable transition from a high asset based savings fund to one that has a wider investment base that will keep pace with inflation and achieve a higher liquidity ratio. We must be prudent in our

Column: 526

investment and not allow a high dependency to occur in any one class of assets.

    I would like to take this opportunity to raise two concerns about the proposed CPF changes.

unhealthy misallocation of our scarce resources. Can the Minister tell us, as a nation, what is the total amount of money committed to property? Those citizens who rely heavily on property assets as a means of retirement are going to be hardest hit. MCDS Delegated Schemes

Public Assistance (PA) Scheme

    Provides a monthly grant to financially distressed Singaporeans who by reason of age, illness, disability or unfavourable family circumstances, are unable to work and have no means of subsistence as well as no one to depend upon. Monthly allowances range from $230 for a single-person household to $670 for a household comprising 4 or more persons.

    Recipients also receive supportive assistance such as free medical benefits at Government/restructured hospitals and Government outpatient clinics. School going children are referred to MOE for supportive assistance and the elderly above 60 years old are matched with volunteers from the Lions Befrienders for assistance in their daily needs.

Special Grant

    Similar to PA Scheme except that the Special Grant is meant to assist non-Singapore citizens.

Interim (Short-term) Financial Assistance Scheme [IFAS]

    Monthly grant is given to help applicants to tide over a difficult period of time. The rates are based on the quantum for Public Assistance but may vary depending on the needs of each case.

Rent & Utilities Assistance Scheme (RUAS)

    Provides short-term relief to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents staying in one, two- or three-room HDB rental flats who are genuinely unable to pay their rent/utilities/conservancy charges. The scheme also assists these families experiencing hardship to move towards self-sufficiency through various support programmes/services provided by participating voluntary welfare organisations (VWOs).

Eligibility Criteria

    (a) Single-parent household with dependent children and without other means of support;

    (b) Family members suffering from chronic illness; or physical, or intellectual or mental disability;

    (c) A household of elderly person/s above age of 60 years and without other means of support;

    (d) Principal Wage Earner passed away, or abandoned or deserted the family, or separated from them;

    (e) Principal Wage Earner detained or imprisoned.

Centre-Based Financial Assistance Scheme for Child Care (CFAC)

    A child care financial assistance scheme for lower-income families, CFAC subsidy is provided on top of the existing Government subsidies to purchase child care services for their pre-schoolers below 7 years old.     The scheme aims to improve the developmental opportunities for children from low-income families and also assists working parents, especially mothers, to return or remain in the labour force. Subsidy ranges from $50 to $250 per child per month. CFAC is extended to all registered child care centres in Singapore and children in the first to fourth birth order of the family qualify for the scheme.

Small Families Improvement Scheme (SFIS)

    Aims to help lower income couples who intend to stay together to keep their families small and to better themselves. It helps families to buy their own HDB flats and to pay for their children's education. The scheme is also extended to widows who have children with educational needs.

    (c) The wife is 40 years of age or below;

    (d) Both husband and wife do not have any GCE `O' or GCE `N' level passes; and

    (e) Both husband and wife earn less than $750 each a month at the time of the application.
